Grant Area District Library
is working in conjunction with GPS to get every high school student a library card. Not only can you check out books, movies and music at the library but when you have your library card you have access to online databases and e-books. This will make it much easier to keep reading!

Parents, if you come in with your child they can get a full privilege card. Otherwise, every student in the Grant School District is eligible for a student card. A student card allows your child to check out two books at a time from our library, but doesn't allow them to check out other items. In addition, it restricts them from borrowing items from any other library. They will have the best service if they have a full privilege card.

Come by the library and get your card!

Erroneous News Report about Grant PS Bond

To the Families, Staff, and Students of Grant Public Schools,

It has been reported overnight and this morning that Grant Public Schools passed a School Bond in the elections yesterday. That is not the case. The Board unanimously decided in March to pull the Bond off of the ballot because of the impending uncertainty with COVID-19. We did not feel it was right to ask families to possibly pay a little more in taxes when people would be facing the possibility of changes in their employment status.

We are not sure why it is being reported in this way, we will try to find some answers today. We just wanted to clarify that GPS chose not to go for the Bond at this time.

Thanks and Go Tigers,

Brett Zuver
Superintendent
Grant Public Schools

Mrs. Gesler took learning to a different level on Friday, February 28. Students had been working on an argument essay about whether bugs should supplement protein for human consumption. As a culminating activity on Friday, students with permission slips were given the option of consuming mealworms, crickets, and grasshoppers. Our very own Mr. Zuver ate a cricket, along with Mrs. Pifer. Mr. Akin and Mr. Jones ate grasshoppers. Mr. Oatis and I ate mealworms. These staff members were kind enough to be videotaped so that I could show the students before the bug-tasting began.
Several students said the mealworms weren't that bad, were crunchy like corn chips, or tasteless. Grasshoppers and crickets mostly left an almond-like or nutty flavor in the mouth. Several did comment that they would have liked dental floss. (I will have to remember that for next year.)
If you wish to try bugs on your own, many entomologists suggest beginning with mealworms; you can dry roast them in your own oven. However, if you have a shellfish allergy, mealworms are not for you.

ONLY SIX DAYS LEFT for your chance to win groceries or gift cards for the holidays while giving to Grant students! The 2019 Gene's Shopping Spree Raffle drawing will be held at 5:00 pm on Monday, December 16. Prizes include a 60 second shopping spree, a $200 gift card, and a $100 gift card.

Elliott and LaRissa Vanderlaan started this annual event in 2017 as a way to give back to the communities that have supported Gene's Family Markets in Grant and Croton.

In the first two years of the raffle, community members won over $2,700 worth of groceries and $600 in gift cards. Last year, over $1,300 in proceeds was also given to Grant students.

For the 2019 raffle, proceeds will be given to the Grant High School Marching Band. The $10 raffle tickets are available for purchase at Gene's Family Market stores in Grant and Croton. Please stop by a store for your ticket today!
